author: Alex Richards
title: Harry Kane needs to 'get nasty' to emulate ex-England star Alan Shearer, believes Dean Ashton
text:
Kane needs to develop a "nasty" side to emulate Shearer (Photo: Getty Images) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Harry Kane has bagged 19 goals in 25 games for Tottenham this season, but the England striker has been told he is some way from being the complete centre-forward. 
Kane, 23, scored a hat-trick for Spurs at Fulham on Sunday, to secure their FA Cup quarter-final place. 
Last year's Premier League golden boot winner has been named in the PFA Team of the Year in both of the last two seasons. 
His goals record since Mauricio Pochettino's arrival at White Hart Lane is also nothing short of outstanding, with Kane having bagged 78 goals in 126 games under the Argentine. 
But ex-England striker Dean Ashton believes he still has some way to go to be mentioned alongside the likes of Alan Shearer - and that includes adding some "nastiness" to his game. Kane put Fulham to the sword (Photo: REUTERS) 
“He is an unbelievable striker, he’s so clinical even with his weaker foot and he’s improving all the time, Ashton told talkSPORT. 
“But there’s so much more he needs to improve on. If he looks at the top English strikers we’ve had, and the top man Alan Shearer in particular – Kane is still so far off him at the moment. 
“He hasn’t got an ounce of nastiness in him, which he needs. You need a little bit of that if you’re going to be absolutely at the very top and be regarded as one of the top strikers. You need that nastiness." Shearer celebrating one of many goals for Newcastle (Photo: Getty) Is Kane nasty enough? (Photo: PA) 
Kane's treble at Craven Cottage ended Spurs' goalscoring struggles from open play, with Pochettino's men having gone without for over 350 minutes. 
Kane struggled to have an impact in last week's back-to-back defeats to Liverpool and Gent, and the lack of 'edge' is an argument that was often thrown his way during his younger days, when struggling to make an impact during loan spells at Norwich and Leicester. 
Still Ashton believes there is plenty of scope for improvement. Ashton knows all about using his frame as a target man (Photo: Getty Images) Kane was part of the Spurs side who disappointed in Belgium on Thursday (Photo: REUTERS) 
"He doesn’t win enough headers, he doesn’t really look like he wants to be in those battles," added the ex-West Ham man. "He’s 6ft 2in - you need to be in those battles as a tall striker. 
“His goal record is fantastic, it speaks for itself. [But] there have been a few games where he hasn’t been involved enough, and that’s where he can improve. 
“Be more of a nuisance, make more of certain balls, be more aggressive when he’s in the box and score more headers. 
"We’re talking about a really great striker already, but I just think there’s so much more he can improve on.”
